page.title: 17THE CUMBERNAULD DOVECOTE
page.content: Near the east gate to the park of Cumbernauld House, there is the site of a stone-walled fruit and vegetable garden built in typical Scottish style. The walls have since been pulled down and the site landscaped, so there is little left of the original garden today.It has been replaced by another one nearer the house. There is a traditional dovecote (pronounced "doocot") in the south-east corner of the old garden. It takes the form of a tall stone-built tower with a conical roof of the pepper-pot type (common in 16th century Scottish architecture). It was used for storage and was entered from the garden. Sometimes pigeons had there nests in the dovecote. { }
